title: 111_hr5258
content: The "Earmark Transparency Act of 2010" establishes a unified and searchable database for congressionally directed spending items. Within six months of enactment, a searchable website will list all requests by Members of Congress for congressionally directed spending items, including fiscal year, bill number, initial request amount, and approved amount by the committee of jurisdiction. The information required for requests by Members of Congress for congressionally directed spending items includes the approved amount, funding details, recipient details, project description, and justification for taxpayer benefit. The website established for congressionally directed spending items allows the public to search, sort, and download all information in a machine-readable format. The website for congressionally directed spending items allows users to search, sort, and download data in a machine-readable format. Users can access total spending items requested by individual Members of Congress and those passed into law by fiscal year. Committees must provide data to the Clerk of the House within 5 days of a spending item request. The Senate must provide initial information on spending requests to the Clerk of the House or Secretary of the Senate for posting on the website within 2 days. Any bill or resolution must meet the requirements of this section to be considered. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include definitions for "congressionally directed spending item" and "Member of Congress." The former refers to specific budget authority requested by a Member of Congress, while the latter includes Senators, Representatives, Delegates, and Resident Commissioners.
